Clinical Judgment Response


Yes the unfolding assignment gave me the opportunity to include a lot of clinical data on the form.


made me see the bigger picture rather than individual pieces of evidence


It improved my clinical judgement skills because it allowed me to utilize my critical thinking skills to accurately assess the patient and prioritize interventions and care. I was able to use theory and apply it to the clinical setting in a real life setting.


It is helpful to plug all information into a patient situation


It taught me how to better prioritize and recognize cues


The unfolding case study helped me organize my approach to the patient and the patient's end goals. It laid out a blue print for how I should be thinking about each patient and their plan of care.


The case studies helped me to think on my feet, however they were difficult because at the bottom line we are not being supplementally taught in class which makes these case studies difficult to do.


Unfolding case studies are far more applicable to practice and assist with forming critical thinking skills in the clinical setting.


It helped to make you think about everything in a nursing way with the past information.














Clinical Judgment Response


It is a bit repetitive, also some sections are unclear on the directions


I hated it, it was very time consuming. I was trying to pass tests that determine my grades and had to focus on the case study. That being said after successfully completing it I felt empowered. One would have been good enough for the semester.


Did not change or impact my critical thinking/judgement at all


Did not improve or challenge clinical judgement. Impairs time spent developing actual skills and requires more on the patient’s charts than actual time allotted.


It was somewhat difficult this semester mainly because the focus assessments were different than the previous example. For example, it was difficult to find the body systems in regards to treatment of patients with mental health disorders. It was harder to pin point what the patient needed. Last semester it was more obvious on what I had to do for my patient because alot of it was objective data rather than subjective. It gave me a different way of thinking to help benefit my patient. I feel that a lot of the questions were repetitive and not necessary. I spent most of my time trying to understand the questions rather than the information needed to answer.


The unfolding case study was beyond our comprehension at this stage of our nursing careers. It felt as if we were unable to completely comprehend what was being asked of us until the end of the semester. My entire clinical group did not begin the project until the end of the semester where we had the knowledge to complete the project but by that point it was a lot of work to be done in a short amount of time.


It was too repetitive and too long. There's a way to have critical thinking and meaningful responses in a shorter more organized manner. The unfolding case study was too stressful with little guidance and instruction. It is not applicable to all clinical rotations.
